Campus security Head Robert
Larkin said yesterday that he is
conducting an ongoing study of
campus crime comparing this
year's rate to last year's.
"There's some concern that
campus crime is greater this year,
but at this time I don't think so,"
stated Larkin.

of crime on campus and within
the surrounding neighborhoods
has probably decreased, though
he will not be certain until he
concludes his study next week.

Very low voter turnout expected
By JAN HAMMERMAN
Suppose they held an election
and nobody voted. That
approximates the situation
Baltimore City faces tomorrow as
one of the most lackluster
municipal campaigns in recent
memory draws mercifully to a

close.

William Donald Schaefer

Local woman abducted and raped
A 20-year-old woman was
abducted from the eastern fringe
of the campus and subsequently
raped last Thursday night,
Northern District Police
reported.
The incident occurred at
approximately 9:15 p.m.
The woman, a local resident,
was picked up by an unidentified
male while she was walking north
on Charles Street. The assailant
drove her to Loch Raven where
he raped her in "a wooded area,"
the police said.
The victim was not otherwise
injured, police said, although she
was in "an extremely agitated
mental state" when she reported
the incident.
Police were unable to
immediately obtain a clear
description of the incident or the

building."
The Baltimorean will be used
to help meet the demand for
more University-owned student
housing.
The purchase of the building is
apparently a satisfactory first
step in meeting student housing
demands to everyone, except the
members of the surrounding
community.
Charles Kelly, President of the
Charles Village Civic Association,
said that while residents realize
there is nothing they can legally
do to stop the Hopkins purchase,
many feel embittered towards
the University for the way in
which the deal was made.
The residents feel they should
have been consulted early in the
process of the purchase, Kelly
asserted.
"It's sort of like a great big
giant going out to take a bite.
You wonder next time how big a
bite he's going to take.
"The area is becoming a very
university-oriented area," Kelly
added. "The residents are
concerned the University may
buy more."
On more immediate concerns,
people in the Charles Village area

from which the crime rate is
determined include only reported
crimes, since no estimate of
Unreported crime is used.
"Northern District police say
that this neighborhood seems
quieter than it did at this time
last year," he said.
Larkin stated that the study of
the crime rate will continue
throughout the year so that the
campus security force will be
able to more accurately assess the
significance of individual
incidents.
Thus far this year, two
unarmed assaults and one armed
assault have been reported police.
The Thursday rape incident
was not considered a campus
crime because it did not involve a
Hopkins student and because it
was not reported to security.

While city elections are usually
bland, this year's contest has
been outright boring. Even the
Democratic primary in
September, which usually
features more than a few close
races, attracted scant interest.
Four reasons account for this
situation. First, the people of the
city believe that Mayor William
Donald Schaefer has indeed done
a good job during his first term.
Moreover, the Mayor faced little
opposition in the primary, as
expected, permitting him to keep
his confident image intact. To be
sure, Schaefer has made a good
showing as the City's number one
cheerleader—rushing from Italian
festivals to Spanish fiestas.
However, his concrete
contributions are not nearly as
obvious. The lack of candidates
has allowed Schaefer to escape
either defending his programs or
announcing new objectives.
The Mayor's opponer.et is an
unknown 41--year-old
housewife—Claudette Chandler.
The ex-schoolteacher's efforts
have drawn little notice, though
she would stand a slim chance of
winning in a municipality where
voter registration runs six to one
Democrat, even if she received
greater publicity.
The contest for City Council
President is somewhat more
interesting. Walter Orlinslcy, a
Johns Hopkins graduate and
former epicurean supreme, won a
clear-cut victory in the primary.
His opponent, Reverend Mariom
C. Bascom, has attracted
significant attention because of
his background as a community
leader and his vigorous campaign
stressing racial unity. Still,
Orlinsky should prevail easily.
Hyman Pressman is running
uncontested- for the
Comptroller's post. Pressman, the
self proclaimed "watch dog" of
the Baltimore City ledger, writes

perhaps the most amusing poetry
this side of Ali. His victory
parties which are usually assured,
rank as the best among the local
politicos.
Only two City Council
districts seem to warrant general
election interest. The second
district, which encompasses
Hopkins, will probably send
Clarence Burns, Mary Pat Clarke,
and Nathan C. Irby to the
Council. Clarke, running for her
first public office, is a local
resident and a standout member
in the Greater Homewood
Community Corporation.
The fifth district, which
includes much of West,
Northwest and North Baltimore,
will soon find out if a Black
write-in candidate, Norman V. A.
Reeves, can defeat one of the
three Democratic nominees. In
the primary campaign, Reeves
failed to gain a finalist slot on the
Democratic ticket due in part to
the fact that another participant
with the same last name was
included on the ballot at the
last moment. Since that time, he
has waged a vigorous battle in the
hope that he can get enough
votes from the West and
Northwest Baltimore Black
community to produce a victory.

Rev. Mariom Bascom

LUNCH DISCUSSION
All persons are invited to join
an informal women's discussion
group on Thurs., Nov. 5, at noon

The History of Ideas Club will

Francisco Madeira, a
Portuguese activist and
economist, will speak on the
current situation in Portugal,
Thurs. Nov. 6, at 8 pm at thc

Cathedral Streets). On a tour of

Revolutionary United Front
(FUR), a grouping of
revolutionary organizations. As

have been taking important steps
in the direction of controlling
their own destinies, Madeira has
been working with councils of
workers in Lisbon to help them
learn to run factories for
themselves, the forum in
Baltimore is sponsored by the
Baltimore Portugal—Angola
Solidarity Committee.

Membership cards will be given

Ethics Board nearing completion of procedural work
By LAINY STEPHANS
The new Academic Ethics
Board has almost finished
defining its hearing procedures
and composing its by-laws, as its
members prepare to introduce
the Homewood Division to a new
method of academic governance.
The Ethics Board, composed
of six students appointed by the
Student Council and four faculty
members selected by the
Academic Council, replaces the
Honor Comm ission , which was
disbanaea last Spring.
Joan McDermott, the panel's
chairwoman, said the Board has
been meeting for the past three
weeks to "determine the role it
Should play in handling cases of
violations of academic integrity."
The Board is now involved in one
hearing of alleged cheating,
McDermott said.
The panel, comprised of
faculty members Charles
Westgate, Electrical Engineering,
John Gryder, Chemistry, Richard
Goldthwaite, History and
Michael Hooker, Philosophy, as
well as students McDermott,
Robert Poynter, Jeremy
Thompson, Barbara Barrett,
Peter Geldner, and John Piccone,
was given authority to handle
academic violations by the Ethics
Constitution ratified by students
this fall.
''According to this
Constitution, if students see
cheating going on, they are
advised to sit down with the
student and discuss it with him,"
said McDermott.
"If students don't want to
confront the student, they can go
to the professor and tell him
cheating has occurred."
Unlike the Honor System, the
Ethics Constitution does not
require that the student leveling
the charge reveal the name of the

person he has seen cheating.
"Part of the purpose of the
new Board is not to simply
convict one person but to stop
cheating on a broader scale—by
students suggesting things like
alternate seating to professors,"
McDermott said.
"If a student has guts, he can
still tell the professor the name
of a student he's seen cheatinr
McDermott said the Board
hopes the professor and accused
student can reach resolution
without the Board's intervention.
"This agreement is not written
into our Constitution, but we are
conscious that the faculty
doesn't particularly like the
hassles of these trials and the
students don't like the burden of
being an accuser."
If the professor and student
cannot come to an agreement
over the charge, the professor can
write a formal statement of
accusation to the Board.
"Students who want to start a
hearing for cheating without
involving the faculty, can also
make an accusation," the Board's
Chairperson said.
Hearings
The hearing that follows
includes a five-person panel of
three students and two faculty
members of the Board, one
Board member acting as presiding
official, the accuser, and the
accused.
Unlike the Honor Commission
trials held in the past, where both
the accuser and the accused were
allowed to have undergraduate
students serve as their counsels,
only the accused can bring his
counsel under the new system.
In the past, the accused and
the accuser came in at separate
times. Now both are in the
hearing room for the entire trial
and must confront each other

directly, McDermott said.
While a unanimous vote was
required for a guilty verdict in
the past, McDermott said four
guilty votes now constitute a
verdict.
The Honor Commission could
hand down only one penalty
when a guilty verdict was
given—failure of the course.

Under the new Ethics Board,
penalties can range from a retake
of a test to expulsion from the
University.
"I definitely think this Board
will work," said member Robert
Poynter, one of eight people who
drew up the Ethic Board's
Constitution this summer.
"I think this is a very sound

Patrick Oliphant visits Hopkins
Patrick Oliphant, the man who
refuses to meet politicians,
consented to meet the public
yesterday as
the MSE
Symposium entered its final
week.
"I dislike 'em," said the
Pulitzer Prize-winning editorial
cartoonist of the breed he has
avoided since meeting—and, to
his dismay, liking—Barry
Goldwater.
"I was afraid it would ruin by
objectivity," he explained. I've
made a point of not meeting
politicians ever since. As far as
I'm concerned, all of them can be
treated with disdain."
In an hour-long slide
presentation, Oliphant
commented on the development
of the modern editorial cartoon
style, crediting early and modern
innovators ranging from Daumier
to the New Yorker's Chon Day
with inspiring artists to "a
graphic expression of political
feelings."
The techniques of cartooning
have remained essentially the
same, according to Oliphant,
though technical proficiency and
the sophistication of the subject
matter have improved. "Basic
graphic ideas can be taken from
one age and applied to the
next—and they still work," he

SC Education Committee named
By ANDREW ALBSTEIN
The Student Council selected
26 undergraduates last week to
serve as departmental
coordinators for its
newly -formed Education
Committee.
The 26 students will serve as a
liason between the Council and
the academic departments, with
one student assigned to each
department.
The student coordinators "are
intended to be a continuous
personal means of input into the
departments through department
chairmen," stated SC President
Mike Lenardo. The student
coordinator should make "as
much contact between himself
and the members of his
department as possible," Lenardo
added.
An outgrowth of the Council's
Academic eports Os last year,

the Education Committee is an
attempt on the part of the
Council to follow up and
continue the work of
undergraduate departmental
evaluation which began with the
reports last year.
Through the student
coordinators, the Council hopes
to maintain a hand in the
decision -making process
concerning undergraduate
academics.
Problems
According to Lenardo, the
student coordinators will be
responsible for handling student
complaints about individual
faculty members as well as
general problems with the
curriculum.
He said that if, for example, a
professor in a Oven department is
not fulfilling his academic
responsibilities, it would be the

charge of the coordinator for
that department to "find out
why these people are not
teaching the undergraduates and
to focus on the problem."
Lenardo asserted that he is
confident that maintaining
personal contact with the
departments through one
individual is the most effective
manner of effecting changes in
academic programming.
The coordinators will try to
work any ! problems out with the
professors and the department
chairmen, and will bring
problems to the SC as a last
resort, Lenardo said.
The education Committee has
been meeting since September.
Steve Lovejoy took over the
chairmanship of the committee
after Jeff Weiss left Hopkins. SC
Reps Andy Davis and Gail lngber
are also on the committee.

Despite his humor, Dick Gregory's politics fall short
By KEN SOKOLOW
Some things just haven't
changed from the late sixties.
College audiences still respond
with great enthusiasm to Dick
Gregory, and the government still
hassles him. Gregory made that
accusation right from the start:
"You know, I like to work this
close to CIA headquarters—that
way those dudes can't get
traveling expenses." So there is
one advantage to being in
Baltimore after all—if you
happen to be Dick Gregory.
There's nothing funny about
people starving. Dick Gregory is a
social activist working to alleviate
the hunger problem in the United
States and the rest of the world.
He is also a humorist—one
possessed with that rarest of all
gifts—the ability to stand in front
of a large group of people and
make them laugh. He is
apparently unwilling to give up
humor in his effort to raise
people's consciousness of an issue
so important and so horrifying
that it would, one might think,
preclude humor. It was
interesting to see how Gregory
tried to resolve this tension.
After establishing at
atmosphere of anxiety with his
initial CIA crack and a hint that
"The Company" indeed had
representatives right there in
Shriver Hall last Thursday night,
Gregory relaxed and told a few
innocuous Jaws jokes (e.g. "my
cousin's so afraid of being bitten
he hasn't been to the toilet in six
months"). Americans are afraid
of the wrong things; the state of
the economy deserves more
thought than killer sharks.
Working the theme of high
prices, Gregory then launched
into a wildly funny comic
fantasy of the coming sugar
panic: sugar junkies hanging out

on street corners carrying coffee
cups, trying to get a fix; a new
breed of ruthless cop—the
sugar-buster—with his fearsome
cockroach assistants trained to
detect sugar in a parallel to
marijuana-sniffing canines
currently employed by the Freds.
I waited for the inevitable George
Carlin line ("sugar's so expensive
now they're cuttin' it with horse
in the A & P"), but Gregory
didn't use it. When you reach a
certain level in the profession,
you don't steal from other
comedians.
There followed a digression on
that legendary figure of ghetto
folklore: the cockroach ("the
first time I was called nigger was
by a cockroach; you sprayed 'em
with Black Flag and it just got
'em high'.). They audience loved
it, but where was all this leading?
To yet more familiar ground: the
mocking of racial stereotypes and
discredited politicians ("Nixon
was a po' white boy who stole
too much too fast" whereas
"when we gets the shopping bag
full, we quit").
The the, politician theme
brought up a serious concern of
Gregory's. He believes the
assassinations of J.F.K., Malcolm
X, R.F.K., Martin Luther King,
Jr., Mrs. Martin Luther King, Sr.,
as well as the attempts on George
Wallace and Gerald Ford were all
the result of conspiracies or one
big conspiracy. Patty Hearst fit in
there somewhere, too. I'm
lumping all these events together
in a vague manner, simply
because that's what Gregory did
in his presentation here. A more
brutal commentator than myself
would call this view paranoid; I'll
suspend judgment until I see
Gregory's evidence. After all, the
events of the last decade and a
half in this country have divested

that word "paranoid" of most,if
not all, of its meaning. Gregory
cut short his tangent in
mid-course; he said he didn't
have time to go into the
assassination controversy in
detail but gave an address to
write to for more information.
The assassination references
marked the end of the laughs.
Gregory was angry and serious
now; he had started out funny
with the anger subdued. One now
realized (if one was not already
familiar with Gregory's outlook)
that the notion of a big
Conspiracy is central to his world
view, and that American
corporations seemed to be at the
heart of this Conspiracy to
starve, to hoard, to poison, to
malnourish, to deceive, to
conceal. And the American
public, out of despairing
resignation or mindless
complacency, refuses to
acknowledge the existence of the
Conspiracy, let alone to fight it.
"The whole country's gone stone
crazy," Gregory lamented.
"We're locked into a death
syndrome."

large portion of the world's food
supply out of concern for their
own profits. This priviliged few,
he claims, constitute a genuine
ruling class, controlling the
government, formulating social
policy, and generally engineering
"the Conspiracy." "The rest of
you white folks are just niggers
to them."
"Y'all got a big job. Turn this
thing around," Gregory urged,
leaving the audience with some
hope that the Conspiracy can still

"What's this institution all

live human beings to go to a
library and read a dead
book—and you pay for it."

"There's a handful of rich supporting food co-operatives
aristocratic white folks running and UNICEF, and—get
this country," who manipulate a this—agitating for reform of the

nation's food policy within the
existing political system. "We
need federal legislation to
subsidize the eater; we've been
subsidizing the farmer." One
wonders how Gregory, with his
view of a Conspiracy controlling
the government, can seriously
expect the federal legislature to
do anything to solve the hunger
problem. After all, isn't Congress
either part or puppet of the
conspiratorial power structure he
postulated? Gregory's remedies,
vague, individualist, voluntaristic,
piecemeal, and tepid, are no
match for the problem he
outlined. His plan for selling
basic staples like beans and rice
for ten cents a 'pound and
subsidizing the producers is
wroth exploring, but what if the
Congress refuses to pass the
enabling laws? After all, our
Chief Executive not so long ago
responded to hundreds of
thousands of people marching on
Washington to end the Vietnam
War by watching a football game
on the tube.
Gregory urged his Hopkins
audience to write to him at PO
Box 266 Plymouth,
Massachusetts 02360 for more
information about how to
survive, how to discipline one's
self, and how to feed the hungry.
I'm certainly going to write to
him, to see if he has a more
nherent program than the one
he presented here. For all his
concern and sincerity, despite the
brilliant insights in his humor,
Dick Gregory as an economist
and political analyst leaves much
to be desired.
My views are probably not in
concordance with those of most
of the audience, which responded
with great enthusiasm to
Gregory's lecture. Perhaps I
missed something.

Mediocrity reigns: too many students get good grades
(CPS)—There's more than one
kind of inflation that college
administrators are complaining
about.
Grade inflation has
drawn the criticism of
administrators throughout the
country who are beginning to
question how many students
deserve the grades they get.
As evidence, they point to
Scholastic Aptitude Test (SAT)
scores for college-bound seniors
Which are falling to new lows at
the same time that grade point
averages are climbing.
At the University of
Oklahoma, where the average
grade in one college is a 3.0,
Dean Paige Mulhollen said
recently that people hiring
graduates "are going to begin to
wonder, if everybody we turn
out has a high grade point but

•
*

some of them aren't very
capable. They're going to start
asking us, 'Wait a minute, what
are you doing for us??"
The dean of the school of
education at Arizona State
University was alarmed enough
by the high grades doled out in
the school to put a ceiling on the
number of A's or B's awarded
each quarter.
More than 85% of the school's
students received A's or B's in
fall quarter last year, according
to a survey. Final grades won't be .
able to exceed a 3.0 average for
all undergraduate students under
the new system.
The problem is hardly
confined to Arizona and
Oklahoma. A study of 197
institutions conducted by a
researcher at Michigan State

University showed that since
1960, the average grade earned
had risen by about one half of a
grade.
As a result, according to the
dean's student assistant at Johns
Hopkins University, "it is

increasingly difficult to
distinguish mediocre students
from the truly outstanding
ones." The assistant claimed that
if the trend is unchecked, grades
will no longer be a valid
measurement of achievement and

Soccer to 'em, Jays!

Blue Jay booters have a chance at NCAA playoff spot
By DAVID KRAUS
A well-rested Hopkins varsity
soccer team heads into an
important week of action, the
results of which could well
determine whether or not the
team will see post-season NCAA
playoff action.
The Blue Jays have not had a
game since last week's 1-0 thriller

over Loyola and spent much of
the weekend preparing
themselves for a pair of key
matches this week.
Division I rival Georgetown
University provides the
opposition for the first of these
contests when they invade
Homewood tomorrow afternoon.
Although the Hoyas do not have

an impressive record, Hopkins
coach Bob Oliver is far from
confident of victory.
"We were as flat as a pancake
when they beat us 2-0 last year,"
the coach commented. "They're
not going anywhere this year and
they'll be very relaxed."
Immediately following the
game, the results will be

telephoned into Joe Lyles, the
Athletic Director at Washington
and Lee University, and the
chairman of the NCAA Division
III Selection Committee for the
Southern Region. This is the
body that will make the decision
as to the four teams from this
region that will participate in the
Division III soccer championship

Gridders ground by Greyhounds, lose 40-20
pass receptions by Joe Devlin.
However, with a first down on
the Greyhound 6-yard line, the
Blue Jays were unable to cross
the goal line on successive thrusts
by Brett Miles, Jurgenson,
Bender, and Dave Emala. Cox
remarked, "One of our linemen
missed a block on the last play.
Otherwise, Emala would've
scored."
Moravian reSponded by going
99 yards in eight plays, capped
by Bob Ternosky's 42-yard
touchdown dash.
Midway through the second
quarter, Hopkins cut the deficit
to 14-7 as Dave Emala completed
an 80-yard drive with a 38-yard
pass reception from Bender.
"Emala showed a lot of poise and
maturity after being switched
from quarterback. He caught five
passes in his first game at
wingback," indicated Cox.
Moravian again responded with
a touchdown drive, culminated
when Vince Pantalone caught a
pass behind Miek Rh-odey in the
corner of the end zone.
A personal foul call stalled the
next Blue Jay drive and the
Moravian second-string scored
three plays later on a half-back
option pass from Keith Walcott
to Calvin Stoudt, who was being
covered by Norbeck. "We had a
mixup defensively. There was
confusion between our end and
halfback on who covered the
pitch to the halfback. Norbeck
mistimed his jump and was
already on the way down when
the ball got there," Cox noted.
The Blue Jay mentor
summarized the first half by
stating, "We just didn't make the
big plays, and they did. The
defense was extremely erratic."
In the anticlimatic second half,
the gridders yielded touchdowns
on a 56-yard return of a Dave

Emala punt and on a 90-yard
touchdown burst by reserve
quarterback Dave Kishbaugh.
Both touchdowns scored by
Hopkins were the result of
fumble recoveries in Moravian
territory by the Blue Jay defense.
Late in the third quarter, Brett
Miles caught a safety valve pass
from Bender and bulled the last
nine yards for the second
Hopkins touchdown of the game.
With two minutes remaining in
the contest, Mike Jurgenson
carried four yards for a
touchdown to complete the
scoring for the game.

By STEVE HAAS
Committing several crucial
first-half mistakes which virtually
cost them the ballgame, the
Hopkins football team fell to
Moravian, 40-20, in a Saturday
encounter in Bethlehem,
Pennsylvania.
Commenting on his squad's
third consecutive defeat, Blue
Jay coach Dennis Cox
explained,"We lost this game for
several reasons. The loss to
Towson last week (a 55-6
trouncing), plus the fact that we
didn't know what type of team
we were playing and playing the
game there in a stadium we had
never seen before hurt us. There
was not as much emotional
preparation as for a natural
rivalry like Swarthmore or
Dickinson."
Numerous key breakdowns
throughout the first half
prevented the gridders from
keeping the score close and
ultimately caused a 27-7 halftime
deficit that the Jays never
overcame.
Hopkins recovered a Moravian
fumble within the first two
minutes in Greyhound territory
and failed to capitalize as
quarterback Tom Bender
fumbled the ball away three
plays later.
Moravian needed only five
plays to complete a 60-yard
touchdown drive, aided by
ineffective Blue Jay tackling and
a penalty called against them
inside their own 10-yard line.
Trailing 7-0, Hopkins fumbled
away the ensuing kickoff, but
the Blue Jay defense prevented
further damage as Bill Norbeck
recoverded a Moravian fumble on
the JHU 13-yard line.
The Blue Jays then mounted a
13-play drive, including a 24-yard
run by Mike Jurgenson and two

A 20-year-old woman was
abducted from the eastern fringe
of the campus and subsequently
raped last Thursday night,
Northern District Police
reported.
The incident occurred at
approximately 9:15 p.m.
The woman, a local resident,
was picked up by an unidentified
male while she was walking north
on Charles Street. The assailant
drove her to Loch Raven where
he raped her in "a wooded area,"
the police said.
The victim was not otherwise
injured, police said, although she
was in "an extremely agitated
mental state" when she reported
the incident.
Police were unable to
immediately obtain a clear
description of the incident or the

The Baltimorean will be used
to help meet the demand for
more University-owned student
housing.
The purchase of the building is
apparently a satisfactory first
step in meeting student housing
demands to everyone, except the
members of the surrounding
community.
Charles Kelly, President of the
Charles Village Civic Association,
said that while residents realize
there is nothing they can legally
do to stop the Hopkins purchase,
many feel embittered towards
the University for the way in
which the deal was made.
The residents feel they should
have been consulted early in the

asserted.
"It's sort of like a great big
giant going out to take a bite.
You wonder next time how big a
bite he's going to take.
"The area is becoming a very
university-oriented area," Kelly
added. "The residents are
concerned the University may
buy more."
On more immediate concerns,
people in the Charles Village area

from which the crime rate is
determined include only reported
crimes, since no estimate of
Unreported crime is used.
"Northern District police say
that this neighborhood seems
quieter than it did at this time
last year," he said.
Larkin stated that the study of
the crime rate will continue
throughout the year so that the

able to more accurately assess the

Thus far this year, two

The Thursday rape incident
was not considered a campus

While city elections are usually
bland, this year's contest has
been outright boring. Even the
Democratic primary in
September, which usually
features more than a few close
races, attracted scant interest.
Four reasons account for this
situation. First, the people of the
city believe that Mayor William
Donald Schaefer has indeed done
a good job during his first term.
Moreover, the Mayor faced little
opposition in the primary, as
expected, permitting him to keep
his confident image intact. To be
sure, Schaefer has made a good
showing as the City's number one
cheerleader—rushing from Italian
festivals to Spanish fiestas.
However, his concrete
contributions are not nearly as
obvious. The lack of candidates
has allowed Schaefer to escape
either defending his programs or
announcing new objectives.
The Mayor's opponer.et is an
unknown 41--year-old
housewife—Claudette Chandler.
The ex-schoolteacher's efforts
have drawn little notice, though
she would stand a slim chance of
winning in a municipality where
voter registration runs six to one
Democrat, even if she received
greater publicity.
The contest for City Council
President is somewhat more
interesting. Walter Orlinslcy, a
Johns Hopkins graduate and
former epicurean supreme, won a
clear-cut victory in the primary.
His opponent, Reverend Mariom
C. Bascom, has attracted
significant attention because of
his background as a community
leader and his vigorous campaign
stressing racial unity. Still,
Orlinsky should prevail easily.
Hyman Pressman is running
uncontested- for the
Comptroller's post. Pressman, the
self proclaimed "watch dog" of
the Baltimore City ledger, writes

perhaps the most amusing poetry
this side of Ali. His victory
parties which are usually assured,
rank as the best among the local
politicos.
Only two City Council
districts seem to warrant general
election interest. The second
district, which encompasses
Hopkins, will probably send
Clarence Burns, Mary Pat Clarke,
and Nathan C. Irby to the
Council. Clarke, running for her
first public office, is a local
resident and a standout member
in the Greater Homewood
Community Corporation.
The fifth district, which
includes much of West,
Northwest and North Baltimore,
will soon find out if a Black
write-in candidate, Norman V. A.
Reeves, can defeat one of the
three Democratic nominees. In
the primary campaign, Reeves
failed to gain a finalist slot on the
Democratic ticket due in part to
the fact that another participant
with the same last name was
included on the ballot at the
last moment. Since that time, he
has waged a vigorous battle in the
hope that he can get enough
votes from the West and
Northwest Baltimore Black
community to produce a victory.

Rev. Mariom Bascom

Ethics Board nearing completion of procedural work
By LAINY STEPHANS
The new Academic Ethics
Board has almost finished
defining its hearing procedures
and composing its by-laws, as its
members prepare to introduce
the Homewood Division to a new
method of academic governance.
The Ethics Board, composed
of six students appointed by the
Student Council and four faculty
members selected by the
Academic Council, replaces the
Honor Comm ission , which was
disbanaea last Spring.
Joan McDermott, the panel's
chairwoman, said the Board has
been meeting for the past three
weeks to "determine the role it
Should play in handling cases of
violations of academic integrity."
The Board is now involved in one
hearing of alleged cheating,
McDermott said.
The panel, comprised of
faculty members Charles
Westgate, Electrical Engineering,
John Gryder, Chemistry, Richard
Goldthwaite, History and
Michael Hooker, Philosophy, as
well as students McDermott,
Robert Poynter, Jeremy
Thompson, Barbara Barrett,
Peter Geldner, and John Piccone,
was given authority to handle
academic violations by the Ethics
Constitution ratified by students
this fall.
''According to this
Constitution, if students see
cheating going on, they are
advised to sit down with the
student and discuss it with him,"
said McDermott.
"If students don't want to
confront the student, they can go
to the professor and tell him
cheating has occurred."
Unlike the Honor System, the
Ethics Constitution does not
require that the student leveling
the charge reveal the name of the

person he has seen cheating.
"Part of the purpose of the
new Board is not to simply
convict one person but to stop
cheating on a broader scale—by
students suggesting things like
alternate seating to professors,"
McDermott said.
"If a student has guts, he can
still tell the professor the name
of a student he's seen cheatinr
McDermott said the Board
hopes the professor and accused
student can reach resolution
without the Board's intervention.
"This agreement is not written
into our Constitution, but we are
conscious that the faculty
doesn't particularly like the
hassles of these trials and the
students don't like the burden of
being an accuser."
If the professor and student
cannot come to an agreement
over the charge, the professor can
write a formal statement of
accusation to the Board.
"Students who want to start a
hearing for cheating without
involving the faculty, can also
make an accusation," the Board's
Chairperson said.
Hearings
The hearing that follows
includes a five-person panel of
three students and two faculty
members of the Board, one
Board member acting as presiding
official, the accuser, and the
accused.
Unlike the Honor Commission
trials held in the past, where both
the accuser and the accused were
allowed to have undergraduate
students serve as their counsels,
only the accused can bring his
counsel under the new system.
In the past, the accused and
the accuser came in at separate
times. Now both are in the
hearing room for the entire trial
and must confront each other

directly, McDermott said.
While a unanimous vote was
required for a guilty verdict in
the past, McDermott said four
guilty votes now constitute a
verdict.
The Honor Commission could
hand down only one penalty
when a guilty verdict was
given—failure of the course.

Under the new Ethics Board,
penalties can range from a retake
of a test to expulsion from the
University.
"I definitely think this Board
will work," said member Robert
Poynter, one of eight people who
drew up the Ethic Board's
Constitution this summer.
"I think this is a very sound

Patrick Oliphant, the man who
refuses to meet politicians,
consented to meet the public
yesterday as
the MSE
Symposium entered its final
week.
"I dislike 'em," said the
Pulitzer Prize-winning editorial
cartoonist of the breed he has
avoided since meeting—and, to
his dismay, liking—Barry
Goldwater.
"I was afraid it would ruin by
objectivity," he explained. I've
made a point of not meeting
politicians ever since. As far as
I'm concerned, all of them can be
treated with disdain."
In an hour-long slide
presentation, Oliphant
commented on the development
of the modern editorial cartoon
style, crediting early and modern
innovators ranging from Daumier
to the New Yorker's Chon Day
with inspiring artists to "a
graphic expression of political
feelings."
The techniques of cartooning
have remained essentially the
same, according to Oliphant,
though technical proficiency and
the sophistication of the subject
matter have improved. "Basic
graphic ideas can be taken from
one age and applied to the
next—and they still work," he

SC Education Committee named
By ANDREW ALBSTEIN
The Student Council selected
26 undergraduates last week to
serve as departmental
coordinators for its
newly -formed Education
Committee.
The 26 students will serve as a
liason between the Council and
the academic departments, with
one student assigned to each
department.
The student coordinators "are
intended to be a continuous
personal means of input into the
departments through department
chairmen," stated SC President
Mike Lenardo. The student
coordinator should make "as
much contact between himself
and the members of his
department as possible," Lenardo
added.
An outgrowth of the Council's
Academic eports Os last year,

the Education Committee is an
attempt on the part of the
Council to follow up and
continue the work of
undergraduate departmental
evaluation which began with the
reports last year.
Through the student
coordinators, the Council hopes
to maintain a hand in the
decision -making process
concerning undergraduate
academics.
Problems
According to Lenardo, the
student coordinators will be
responsible for handling student
complaints about individual
faculty members as well as
general problems with the
curriculum.
He said that if, for example, a
professor in a Oven department is
not fulfilling his academic
responsibilities, it would be the

charge of the coordinator for
that department to "find out
why these people are not
teaching the undergraduates and
to focus on the problem."
Lenardo asserted that he is
confident that maintaining
personal contact with the
departments through one
individual is the most effective
manner of effecting changes in
academic programming.
The coordinators will try to
work any ! problems out with the
professors and the department
chairmen, and will bring
problems to the SC as a last
resort, Lenardo said.
The education Committee has
been meeting since September.
Steve Lovejoy took over the
chairmanship of the committee
after Jeff Weiss left Hopkins. SC
Reps Andy Davis and Gail lngber
are also on the committee.

Despite his humor, Dick Gregory's politics fall short
By KEN SOKOLOW
Some things just haven't
changed from the late sixties.
College audiences still respond
with great enthusiasm to Dick
Gregory, and the government still
hassles him. Gregory made that
accusation right from the start:
"You know, I like to work this
close to CIA headquarters—that
way those dudes can't get
traveling expenses." So there is
one advantage to being in
Baltimore after all—if you
happen to be Dick Gregory.
There's nothing funny about
people starving. Dick Gregory is a
social activist working to alleviate
the hunger problem in the United
States and the rest of the world.
He is also a humorist—one
possessed with that rarest of all
gifts—the ability to stand in front
of a large group of people and
make them laugh. He is
apparently unwilling to give up
humor in his effort to raise
people's consciousness of an issue
so important and so horrifying
that it would, one might think,
preclude humor. It was
interesting to see how Gregory
tried to resolve this tension.
After establishing at
atmosphere of anxiety with his
initial CIA crack and a hint that
"The Company" indeed had
representatives right there in
Shriver Hall last Thursday night,
Gregory relaxed and told a few
innocuous Jaws jokes (e.g. "my
cousin's so afraid of being bitten
he hasn't been to the toilet in six
months"). Americans are afraid
of the wrong things; the state of
the economy deserves more
thought than killer sharks.
Working the theme of high
prices, Gregory then launched
into a wildly funny comic
fantasy of the coming sugar
panic: sugar junkies hanging out

on street corners carrying coffee
cups, trying to get a fix; a new
breed of ruthless cop—the
sugar-buster—with his fearsome
cockroach assistants trained to
detect sugar in a parallel to
marijuana-sniffing canines
currently employed by the Freds.
I waited for the inevitable George
Carlin line ("sugar's so expensive
now they're cuttin' it with horse
in the A & P"), but Gregory
didn't use it. When you reach a
certain level in the profession,
you don't steal from other
comedians.
There followed a digression on
that legendary figure of ghetto
folklore: the cockroach ("the
first time I was called nigger was
by a cockroach; you sprayed 'em
with Black Flag and it just got
'em high'.). They audience loved
it, but where was all this leading?
To yet more familiar ground: the
mocking of racial stereotypes and
discredited politicians ("Nixon
was a po' white boy who stole
too much too fast" whereas
"when we gets the shopping bag
full, we quit").
The the, politician theme
brought up a serious concern of
Gregory's. He believes the
assassinations of J.F.K., Malcolm
X, R.F.K., Martin Luther King,
Jr., Mrs. Martin Luther King, Sr.,
as well as the attempts on George
Wallace and Gerald Ford were all
the result of conspiracies or one
big conspiracy. Patty Hearst fit in
there somewhere, too. I'm
lumping all these events together
in a vague manner, simply
because that's what Gregory did
in his presentation here. A more
brutal commentator than myself
would call this view paranoid; I'll
suspend judgment until I see
Gregory's evidence. After all, the
events of the last decade and a
half in this country have divested

that word "paranoid" of most,if
not all, of its meaning. Gregory
cut short his tangent in
mid-course; he said he didn't
have time to go into the
assassination controversy in
detail but gave an address to
write to for more information.
The assassination references
marked the end of the laughs.
Gregory was angry and serious
now; he had started out funny
with the anger subdued. One now
realized (if one was not already
familiar with Gregory's outlook)
that the notion of a big
Conspiracy is central to his world
view, and that American
corporations seemed to be at the
heart of this Conspiracy to
starve, to hoard, to poison, to
malnourish, to deceive, to
conceal. And the American
public, out of despairing
resignation or mindless
complacency, refuses to
acknowledge the existence of the
Conspiracy, let alone to fight it.
"The whole country's gone stone
crazy," Gregory lamented.
"We're locked into a death
syndrome."

large portion of the world's food
supply out of concern for their
own profits. This priviliged few,
he claims, constitute a genuine
ruling class, controlling the
government, formulating social
policy, and generally engineering
"the Conspiracy." "The rest of
you white folks are just niggers
to them."
"Y'all got a big job. Turn this
thing around," Gregory urged,
leaving the audience with some
hope that the Conspiracy can still
be stopped. But how? Gregory
waited until the last three
minutes of his presentation to
sketch his solutions to the hunger
problem. Before hearing his ideas
for feeding the masses, the
audience was first treated to his
critique of colleges and the
morality of today's college
students.(Shades of Agnew!)
"What's this institution all
about?" he asked rhetorically,
then elaborated. "You walk past
live human beings to go to a
library and read a dead
book—and you pay for it."
College students, to Gregory are
no less complacent and selfish
Injustice
than the rest of the population.
Gregory does not advocate "Smoking pot is not an
birth control as a means of anti-system act! Who supplies it
solving the hunger problem. He `.o you, punk?" The Conspiracy,
to make students—potential
sees a shortage of justice, not a
superfluity of people, as the revolutionaries—more passive, of
cause of the problem. In his view course. Yet Gregory is depending
of the situation in India—based on this hedonistic group which
on a report he claimed the U.N. he chides for its lack of
itself had tried to suppress-65% self-discipline and commitment
of the grain there is consumed by to "do the job," to "turn this

What after all the charisma,
many rodents, not too many
Indians." This perspective was wit, anger, and rhetoric did
probably novel to most of the Gregory have to advocate? It
boiled down to fasting one day a
crowd.
According to Gregory, week, growing your own food,
"There's a handful of rich supporting food co-operatives
aristocratic white folks running and UNICEF, and—get
this country," who manipulate a this—agitating for reform of the

nation's food policy within the
existing political system. "We
need federal legislation to
subsidize the eater; we've been
subsidizing the farmer." One
wonders how Gregory, with his
view of a Conspiracy controlling
the government, can seriously
expect the federal legislature to
do anything to solve the hunger
problem. After all, isn't Congress
either part or puppet of the
conspiratorial power structure he
postulated? Gregory's remedies,
vague, individualist, voluntaristic,
piecemeal, and tepid, are no
match for the problem he
outlined. His plan for selling
basic staples like beans and rice
for ten cents a 'pound and
subsidizing the producers is
wroth exploring, but what if the
Congress refuses to pass the
enabling laws? After all, our
Chief Executive not so long ago
responded to hundreds of
thousands of people marching on
Washington to end the Vietnam
War by watching a football game
on the tube.
Gregory urged his Hopkins
audience to write to him at PO
Box 266 Plymouth,
Massachusetts 02360 for more
information about how to
survive, how to discipline one's
self, and how to feed the hungry.
I'm certainly going to write to
him, to see if he has a more
nherent program than the one
he presented here. For all his
concern and sincerity, despite the
brilliant insights in his humor,
Dick Gregory as an economist
and political analyst leaves much
to be desired.
My views are probably not in
concordance with those of most
of the audience, which responded
with great enthusiasm to
Gregory's lecture. Perhaps I
missed something.

Mediocrity reigns: too many students get good grades
(CPS)—There's more than one
kind of inflation that college
administrators are complaining
about.
Grade inflation has
drawn the criticism of
administrators throughout the
country who are beginning to
question how many students
deserve the grades they get.
As evidence, they point to
Scholastic Aptitude Test (SAT)
scores for college-bound seniors
Which are falling to new lows at
the same time that grade point
averages are climbing.
At the University of
Oklahoma, where the average
grade in one college is a 3.0,
Dean Paige Mulhollen said
recently that people hiring
graduates "are going to begin to
wonder, if everybody we turn
out has a high grade point but

•
*

some of them aren't very
capable. They're going to start
asking us, 'Wait a minute, what
are you doing for us??"
The dean of the school of
education at Arizona State
University was alarmed enough
by the high grades doled out in
the school to put a ceiling on the
number of A's or B's awarded
each quarter.
More than 85% of the school's
students received A's or B's in
fall quarter last year, according
to a survey. Final grades won't be .
able to exceed a 3.0 average for
all undergraduate students under
the new system.
The problem is hardly
confined to Arizona and
Oklahoma. A study of 197
institutions conducted by a
researcher at Michigan State

University showed that since
1960, the average grade earned
had risen by about one half of a
grade.
As a result, according to the
dean's student assistant at Johns
Hopkins University, "it is

increasingly difficult to
distinguish mediocre students
from the truly outstanding
ones." The assistant claimed that
if the trend is unchecked, grades
will no longer be a valid
measurement of achievement and

Soccer to 'em, Jays!

Blue Jay booters have a chance at NCAA playoff spot
By DAVID KRAUS
A well-rested Hopkins varsity
soccer team heads into an
important week of action, the
results of which could well
determine whether or not the
team will see post-season NCAA
playoff action.
The Blue Jays have not had a
game since last week's 1-0 thriller

over Loyola and spent much of
the weekend preparing
themselves for a pair of key
matches this week.
Division I rival Georgetown
University provides the
opposition for the first of these
contests when they invade
Homewood tomorrow afternoon.
Although the Hoyas do not have

an impressive record, Hopkins
coach Bob Oliver is far from
confident of victory.
"We were as flat as a pancake
when they beat us 2-0 last year,"
the coach commented. "They're
not going anywhere this year and
they'll be very relaxed."
Immediately following the
game, the results will be

telephoned into Joe Lyles, the
Athletic Director at Washington
and Lee University, and the
chairman of the NCAA Division
III Selection Committee for the
Southern Region. This is the
body that will make the decision
as to the four teams from this
region that will participate in the
Division III soccer championship

Gridders ground by Greyhounds, lose 40-20

the Greyhound 6-yard line, the
Blue Jays were unable to cross
the goal line on successive thrusts
by Brett Miles, Jurgenson,
Bender, and Dave Emala. Cox
remarked, "One of our linemen
missed a block on the last play.
Otherwise, Emala would've
scored."
Moravian reSponded by going
99 yards in eight plays, capped
by Bob Ternosky's 42-yard
touchdown dash.
Midway through the second
quarter, Hopkins cut the deficit
to 14-7 as Dave Emala completed
an 80-yard drive with a 38-yard
pass reception from Bender.
"Emala showed a lot of poise and
maturity after being switched
from quarterback. He caught five
passes in his first game at
wingback," indicated Cox.
Moravian again responded with
a touchdown drive, culminated
when Vince Pantalone caught a
pass behind Miek Rh-odey in the
corner of the end zone.
A personal foul call stalled the
next Blue Jay drive and the
Moravian second-string scored
three plays later on a half-back
option pass from Keith Walcott
to Calvin Stoudt, who was being
covered by Norbeck. "We had a
mixup defensively. There was
confusion between our end and
halfback on who covered the
pitch to the halfback. Norbeck
mistimed his jump and was
already on the way down when
the ball got there," Cox noted.
The Blue Jay mentor
summarized the first half by
stating, "We just didn't make the
big plays, and they did. The
defense was extremely erratic."
In the anticlimatic second half,
the gridders yielded touchdowns
on a 56-yard return of a Dave

touchdown burst by reserve
quarterback Dave Kishbaugh.
Both touchdowns scored by
Hopkins were the result of

territory by the Blue Jay defense.
Late in the third quarter, Brett
Miles caught a safety valve pass
from Bender and bulled the last
nine yards for the second
Hopkins touchdown of the game.
With two minutes remaining in
the contest, Mike Jurgenson
carried four yards for a
touchdown to complete the
scoring for the game.

highly-rated Terrapin singles
players.

sparked the Blue Jays from her
number one singles spot going all
the way to the finals before
succumbing.

job," noted Dr. Joyce Hogan, the

By STEVE HAAS
Committing several crucial
first-half mistakes which virtually
cost them the ballgame, the
Hopkins football team fell to
Moravian, 40-20, in a Saturday
encounter in Bethlehem,
Pennsylvania.
Commenting on his squad's
third consecutive defeat, Blue
Jay coach Dennis Cox
explained,"We lost this game for
several reasons. The loss to
Towson last week (a 55-6
trouncing), plus the fact that we
didn't know what type of team
we were playing and playing the
game there in a stadium we had
never seen before hurt us. There
was not as much emotional
preparation as for a natural
rivalry like Swarthmore or
Dickinson."
Numerous key breakdowns
throughout the first half
prevented the gridders from
keeping the score close and
ultimately caused a 27-7 halftime
deficit that the Jays never
overcame.
Hopkins recovered a Moravian
fumble within the first two
minutes in Greyhound territory
and failed to capitalize as
quarterback Tom Bender
fumbled the ball away three
plays later.

"He (Lyles) may hold back on

the coach continued, "even
though Friday is supposed to be

The game to which Oliver
referred is this weekend's tough
contest at Washington College.
This match pits two powerful
teams (the Jays are 8-1-1 while
Washington is 9-2) and may well
determine the MAC divisional
champion and a possible NCAA
bid.
Asked about other teams that
may be in the tournament from
this region, the coach mentioned
Lynchburg, Scranton and
Muhlenberg.
"But," he reminded, "that's
just speculation. I don't know
much about some of the teams in
the South (the region stretches
all the way to Florida). Right
now, it's just a game of wait and
see."
In the meantime, tomorrow's
contest will be held on the
Homewood soccer field and will
start at 3 p.m.
